text: We will hear argument in Number 121 Original, Louisiana v. Mississippi.
Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court:
You say the river never found its main course?
--When you say island, Justice Stevens--
Stack Island.
--Well, the original Stack Island of 1881 was 6 miles northeast of that location.
Right.
The boundary is sought to be drawn--
Are you saying that the thalweg was never west of that island?
--Yes, sir.
Mr. Keyser, I'm confused on that point, because I thought that Dr. Easterly testified in answer... there's this colloquy in the third supplemental transcript at 315, 313 to 15.
Yes.
Well, if we speak just in neutral terms about disputed territory, that will take care of that confusion, won't it?
Or the disputed areas, sometimes referred to the accretion along the west bank at Lake Providence.

You said in your brief, I believe, that the line as the master has recommended that it be drawn now cuts through property which has been owned and farmed by Louisiana residents since I think the beginning of this century, and that statement was simply hotly disputed in Mississippi's brief as being a factual misstatement.
One place you would want to look is to the testimony of Albert Surles, who adjoins the property of Mr. Sam House, who is the sheriff of that parish.
Okay.

I can't think of anything, except Robert... you have to recall that Mississippi really only had two witnesses, Austin Smith, who is their expert, and Robert Jarvis, who is the grandson of the Houston family.
Well, that may be, but none of that indicates that a Louisiana family was farming the land since 1900, and I take it it's the Surles' testimony and that alone that you point to.
Yes, sir, and you'll see in the testimony there that there... in fact, the lease was introduced: to evidence.
Okay.
Thank you.
Before we leave the thalweg issue, whether it was west of the disputed territory or not, I confess to be totally at a loss to understand what's going on here.
--No, sir.
Well, I'm talking about the prepatent location.
--It was west of Stack Island before the New Madrid earthquake washed the island away in 1811, and it was west of Stack Island... another problem--
You're saying this isn't Stack Island, isn't that what causes all of this confusion?
--Certainly.

So if we accept the master's reasoning that in fact you can trace the... I'll call it the migration of this piece of land, whatever it's supposed to be called, from the Stack Island which was east of the boundary thalweg originally to the disputed area now, then your argument falls.
--That's correct.
And then you do concede... that was the Dr. Easterly testimony that I read, that the boundary thalweg was west of Stack Island at its formation.
In 1811 or prior years, not at 1994, 1995--
Well, we have just gone through that if this Stack Island continued in existence, then the boundary was west of Stack Island at the island's formation.
--Dr. Easterly's not referring to the Louisiana levee.
And the boundary thalweg, unless Stack Island is washed away, will remain west of Stack Island for all times, unless it is eroded away, and Dr. Easterly confirmed that that was correct.
That's correct, but he's not referring to Lake Providence, he's referring to Mayersville, Mississippi.
I thought he was referring to Stack Island.
No.

Maybe I have this mixed up, but I didn't think it was that complicated, so probably I do have it mixed up, but I thought once upon a time there was a place called Stack Island that used to be part of Mississippi, and there was a big river that flowed to the west of it.
Correct.

And then that big river that flowed to the west of it began to change its channel and began to flow towards the east of it, and the law is that if the river changes like that, that Stack Island still stays part of Mississippi.
I agree with--

So you're all arguing about whether this was one island called Stack Island, which has always existed, but the river changed course, or that there are three or four or five islands that keep coming back and forth and disappearing.
--That's exactly correct.
All right.
That's exactly what--

If that's correct, then looking through this, it seemed to me they made an awfully good case that there was just one island, because they trace it through on all the maps, and then they show that there were cottonwood trees there that are about 100 years old, or 80 years old or something, and they're still there, and it's pretty hard to see how all these trees could have grown on this island that was popping in and popping out, and you have some other evidence, but what is it, because I haven't found it.
--Let me explain what that problem is there.

The only thing I found on your side, or my clerk found so far was that one of these maps, which always talks about Stack Island, had at one point marked through it a thing that said river, or channel, and if you assume there were 50 yards on either side or something it must go through... do you know what I'm thinking of?
I think that was a survey--
Yes, right.
--About what?
That shows this island was popping in and out instead of just being one island.
One of the best things... quickest handles you can get on that is to look at Dr. Easterly's testimony.

Mr. Keyser, when you say that it washed away, do you mean that there was on the surface of the river at that point no land showing, or do you mean that the level of the island in relation to the adjacent river banks dropped sufficiently low so that by the legal definition you employ it was not an island even though there was visible land of some sort there, whatever you might call it?
Both of those are true, both of those statements.
Wasn't there also testimony that with respect to that time a given family was continuously farming the land, so that with respect to that, wasn't there disputed testimony?
They filed affidavits... the island was surveyed--
Well, but isn't that what their affidavit said?
--Correct.
And isn't the master entitled to accept the affidavit?
I think he has to do so with a common sense comprehension of what was going on at the time.
Well, if somebody says, there's nothing there, and somebody else says, we were farming that land there at that time, the master can't have it both ways.
That's true.
If he chooses yours, they're going to say, oh, gee... the other side is going to say, you've got to show common sense, and if he chooses the other side's testimony, that's what you're saying.
Why would the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers draw hydrographic surveys that showed scour pools at the location of the island?

I don't know, but if you want to say it's a choice between whether you're going to accept the testimony of farmers who said they were farming, and a Government agency that drew a map, I don't see anything irrational about saying I'm going to go with the farmers.
--Well, the island was surveyed in 1881, but it washed away in 1883.
And the farmers say no, we were farming it.
--Well, in the hope that it would come back, which it did.
Well, they weren't farming in hope.
They may not have been accurately providing affidavit for the general land office--
Well, somebody could always lie in testimony, that's true.
--With an island elevation of 20 feet and a water elevation of 50 feet, one might doubt the veracity of an affidavit that says there was an ongoing farming operation continuously from year to year.
I don't know, but I'm concerned about 1883, and the master--
Well, that's--
--took the testimony of the farmers, and I still don't know why it's irrational.
--Well, he didn't take the testimony of the farmers.
Took the affidavit of the farmers.
He took... there was an affidavit filed in an effort to kill a fault in a patent application, was what that was about.
In your view, when did this disputed area form?
According to the testimony of the Corps of Engineers chief hydrologist, it started forming in the 1930's.
Your position is, it's 1930, or it's not 1930, when is it?
--It's a gradual process of building on a river bank.
--In the disputed area, roughly, in a 10-year period, or from 1930 if the record tells us, what period of time was it underwater?
Every year.
For how long?
--During high water.
How long does the high water last?
It would depend on the melting of the snow up north.
So in some periods it would be underwater for 3 or 4 months?
--Yes, or longer.
In other words, there is... if I go to the place... what's... it's not a trick.
Major treetops.
So in other words, if we go there right now, there is no land.
Depending on the water elevation.
But no, is it that there is no land there at all, it's below the water, like feet, many, many feet below?
I would imagine if conditions today on October 2nd or 3rd--

And all the witnesses agreed, everybody said... I didn't get that from the report... they all went out to this place of what they're calling Stack Island, and there's no land, it's just water 3 or 4 months a year?
--That is the nature of the river.
But is... am I right in saying that?
--Yes, Your Honor.
So there is no land there, there is just water 3 or 4 months every year, is that the case?
It may be longer than 3 or 4 months.
All right, but not shorter.
It could be shorter.
It's like the Nile Valley.
Correct.
May I go back, then, to my earlier question?
Yes, sir.
Part of your argument, if not your case, then, rests on your claim that this is not an island because it is not high enough in relation to the banks of the river to be called an island.
Correct.

And you're saying that for that reason, even though during some parts of the year there's land here, and indeed there's enough land to have trees, the tops of which look like a forest, it's still not an island, and the island rule, or the island exception, rather, does not apply.
Yes.
Okay.
It wouldn't apply to this--

Why... you in effect then are saying that the island exception should not apply to anything that does not... any body of land sometime above the river, which sometime is located above the surface of the river, which is not... I forget what the rule is, as high as the banks, or something like that.
--If you attempt to take into account every bar and shoal, and if each one of those can represent the legal character of an island, you'll have a thousand boundaries.
But I assume very few of those have been patented to owners like this.
Not on the west bank of the river at Lake Providence.
You know, there is a series of maps that were put in evidence in this case, I assume by Mississippi, and each one has fixed markers.
Yes.
And you come away at the end thinking, well, here is this piece of land that was patented, and it shift and changed through the years, but it's identifiable.
He did look at it, and apparently did rely upon it, and that technique is the subject of a book.
Well, are you suggesting that the island disappeared in the meantime?
--Dr. Winkley said--
Are you saying that as between map A, B, and C in the interstitial period between A and B and B and C, that the body of land disappeared?
--From year to year it did.
They just happened to get there at the fortunate moments when it was appearing, and they never bothered to map during those periods when it had sunk?
Those maps are--
I mean, that's not a believable proposition.
--Those maps are at low water.

All right, then that gets us... all right, then that gets us back to the claim of whether it is or is not an island by legal definition, but it doesn't go to the question of continuity, which Justice O'Connor raised with you.
Well, Dr. Winkley addressed the question of the whole thing being scoured away.
That testimony contradicts the series of maps, does it not?
--Yes, it does, the series--
Once again--
--that Justice O'Connor referred to.

--as with the affidavit by those who claimed to have farmed the land, there is conflicting testimony, and isn't the master entitled to rely on the series of maps, rather than on the testimony of your one expert witness?
Well, we had four.
On this point?
--Yes, sir.
That said it was totally scoured?
--We had Hatley Harrison in the first trial, Mike Mayeux, the surveyor, Dr. Winkley, the corps' hydrologist, and Dr. Easterly.
General Keyser, can I ask you a factual question?
Correct.
And in your view, how long does it have to be submerged before it ceases being an island?
It has to be above ordinary high water to be an island at any time.
Well, I... you're not denying... you're not saying it was never above high water.
Dr. Winkley said there has been no island in the river above high water for any recorded period of history.
It as to be above high water.
Ordinary high water.
And for what period of year, in your view of the evidence, was the island totally submerged, in a typical year?
Well, it would be submerged from after the... I mean, it would be emergent from after the spring floods, generally through the summer, to February, March, April the next year.
So it would be above water more often than it would be submerged.
It's hard to say because of the way the water in the river is.

Well, with reference to the definition of an island, can you give us some idea of how to measure the time that the island has to be above water, or above the high water mark, in order to qualify as an island under your definition?
Once an island is above ordinary high water, it is a fixed place.
Even if it's above high water for just once a year?
Well, yes, if it--
One day a year?
--Ordinary high water--
That's what we're asking.
--Ordinary high water may be in the vicinity of 36 to 38, 40 feet.
--How long does it have to be--
There's no rule on that that I'm aware of.
--So 1 day a year suffices.
I wouldn't go that far.
I thought the definition that the master used was whether or not it was below or above for a protracted period of time.
--I would think it should be, but I've never seen a situation where there was only... if you only had 1 day of ordinary high water, it might qualify, but that's not the case.

Mr. Keyser, going back perhaps more specifically to the question that Justice O'Connor raised with you, in leaving aside for the moment the question of how we're going to define the island... let's just refer to it in a generic... to the disputed area in a generic way.
That's totally incorrect.
Well, how long was the island?
--Along the Lake Providence bank in Louisiana.
Yes, but how long is it, I mean in relation to 6... you're saying it was 6 miles apart, it couldn't--
--Oh, no, no--
--so that statement couldn't be correct.
--Yes, I see what you're getting at.
Thank you.
Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court:
When you say above high water, what do you mean?
--Your Honor, when I say that, I'm talking about constantly.
Permanently.
Now, there may be--
So you disagree as a matter of fact with your opponent's statement that for several months each year it was 40 feet below high water.
--Yes.
Well, where were you all when you were in the boat?
Well--
Didn't you row among--
We rowed among treetops, but there was also water... dry land above the water.
I mean, where was... that what was mixing me up.
Well, what happened was that a part of the time... we motored, we didn't actually row.
But you said that it has to be permanently above high water.
Well, I didn't... if I said that, You Honor... I thought you were asking me... I didn't say it had to be permanently above water.
I'm not talking about permanently above flood tide, or anything.
Yes.

Permanently above normal high water, and so I took your statement to mean that if at the time when you went motoring among the treetops the whole island was underwater, that would contradict your case, but you say the whole island... because I assume that was just normal Mississippi high water at that time.
It was a flood, but Your Honor, I guess that--
You picked a bad time to go, then.
--We wanted to see it at its worst.
--Well, Mr. McCartney, I just wanted to get straight on what you saw out on the boat.
That--
--that there was still some dry land somewhere.
--Your Honor--
The edges of the island got flooded, but the center of the island didn't, is that true?
--Your Honor, that is my recollection at this time, and Mr. Bailess will address that, but that is my recollection, and--
But your further position is that even if there were a total flood, I mean, you can flood a whole long area, it doesn't cease being land.
--No.
Yes.

I mean, as pointed out, we have trees that... evidence that there were trees there that had been 50, 60 years old, and if I may just add to the evidence, in your review of the evidence of permanence, in addition to what the special master laid out in his Appendix D, which is itself overwhelmingly compelling, particularly when compared to the single or... map that they relied on to say that the island was scoured clean, and the bed of the river was scoured clean of this feature in 1883.
Mr. Keyser says four witnesses testified to that, is that right?
That is not so.
Was the scoured clean map I think you were referring to, or one of the briefs referred to as the lunch map?
The lunch map--
Yes.

--which itself, and I'll just... it's credibility is destroyed, or at least seriously impaired, because one of their experts gives it to the other expert in the middle of trial, and he takes that map, and he says, oh, you know, this land was underwater, and we say, well, wait a minute, here are affidavits given in 1885 that say these people were farming--
Yes, but that map does show a channel of the river going right over the island, doesn't it?
--And... and he says, how can they be farming land that's underwater, and we say, that is a good question.
Mr. McCartney, do we know who did the lunch map?
We do not.
--is the author unknown?
Author unknown--
Can you get maps into evidence like that?
--Well--
--without knowing--

--Your Honor, to be perfectly frank with you, we wanted that map in evidence, because the reliance on that map and the circumstances in which it was found... and it was a total reliance... utterly destroyed the credibility of Mr. Winkley, and so we were perfectly happy for him to rely on this map that mysteriously appears at lunch and say, yes, this is what I'm relying on, and therefore this island was scoured away and washed away and ceased to exist, and so--
--Mr. McCartney, what is your view of our duty to give deference to the master's findings of fact?
--Your Honor, I've taken a position on that in a previous argument that you are free to take your own factfindings, and that the clearly erroneous rule does not apply.
Thank you, Mr. McCartney.
Thank you.
Mr. Bailess.
Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court:
Well, I wish you had, too, because it sounds like something like a giant shell game in the river, now you see it, now you don't, and no, it's... the island's up here 6 miles away.
Justice O'Connor, I would... you mentioned the overlay exhibits which, it takes a little time to examine those exhibits.
May I get specific about that with a question that I raised with Mr. Keyser?

Justice Souter, the only way that I know to answer that question is to say, if you will look at who was testifying to come up with those percentages, it was Dr. Winkley on cross-examination, so Louisiana's own expert witness testified to that.
What is your comment on Mr. Keyser's statement that the island... or the land masses were 6 miles apart, and for that reason, given their sizes, there could not have been such an overlap?
--Your Honor, Mr. Keyser attempted to talk about two islands when we tried this case the first time in Vicksburg before Judge Barbour in 1989.
Well, is it 6 miles away on the--
No, sir, it's not nearly 6 miles away.
--Well, do you stand by the statement which you attribute to the witness for the other side that there was this 65 percent identity over time between 1882 and 1937?
I think it's substantially correct, Your Honor.
You adopted it in your brief.
--I did.
Yes.
Give or take 10 percent, I believe you will, sir.
Okay.
Let me correct one other thing that is misleading.
Were you on this boat trip?
Yes, ma'am, I was.
And was there a part of the disputed area that was above the waterline on that boat trip, or was there not?

Justice O'Connor, we did not... as I mentioned just a moment ago, we did not see dry land on that trip, mainly because to get in there... there was current in the river, and we would have had to go in between trees to get to that area, and we felt like that was not an appropriate thing to do under the circumstances.
You couldn't see it in the distance.
--We did not see it.
Well, do you acknowledge that at times the island is completely submerged--
No.
--in the river?
No, Your Honor, I do not.
Well, do we look at the high water mark or the low water mark?

--Your Honor, we take the position that an island is an area of land surrounded by water that has permanent features, i.e. vegetation, i.e. 70-year-old trees, that is capable of sustaining vegetation, and in 1881, when this island was surveyed by the General Land Office of the United States by a deputy surveyor, it had trees that were 60 to 70 years old at that time.
Mr. Bayless, what is the difference in altitude between the ordinary high water mark and the zero gauge level on the Mississippi River?
According to Mr. Winkley, Justice Stevens, it's 35 feet.
What do you think it really is?
The Corps of Engineers establishes a standard low water, which is then termed zero gauge.
Right.
The top bank is in the neighborhood of 35 feet.

Well now, on your... when you talk about the land being visible, are you talking about there being enough land above the ordinary high water mark, or enough land above the zero gauge, when you try to define the island?
Your Honor, above zero gauge, Stack Island was a tremendous island in size.
All right.
At--
But which is the significant standard for us to look at, zero gauge, or high water mark?
--Our position is standard low water, Your Honor.
Well, is standard low water the same as zero gauge?
--Pardon me?
Is standard low water the same as zero gauge?
Yes, Your Honor.
I want to be sure.
Mr. Winkley testified, when they came up with this proposition that to be a true island it had to be above mean high water, that's the term that.
And top bank means what?

According to Dr. Winkley, it is approximately 35 feet above zero gauge which, to determine that, what he did in his testimony was, he took a period of time, and he plotted heights of the river during the 1870's to the 1880's.
But now, there are levees in this area.
Yes.
And how high are the... what is the top of the levees, how high above the--

--I can't tell you from memory, but I believe I am correct in saying this, that the 50-foot contour on Stack Island that exists according to the 1993 hydrographic survey that is in evidence is at least as high as the top of the levee.
--Did I understand you to say earlier that even accepting the other side's definition of an island as requiring land equal to or above, what is it, top--
Top bank is what they say.
--Yes, that Stack Island would qualify?
That is correct, Justice Souter.
And qualified in 1881?
That is correct, and Dr. Winkley admitted that.
And do I also understand... you didn't say this explicitly, but I took this as implied, and I want to make sure I understand you.
That is absolutely correct.
Okay.
Let me answer that in this way.
To the low water mark.
It ought to be.
Am I correct that there has never been any dispute in this litigation that at the time of the original patent... which was what, 1881, I think?
It was surveyed in '81--
Okay.
--issued in '88.
All right.
To my knowledge, it has never been contested, Your Honor.
Okay.
Your Honor, if it truly disappeared by the natural processes of the river... that is, the channel of the river scoured that island away, then the island in my opinion would be no more.

I was going to say, we don't have to get into that issue on your theory, because there is at least an evidentiary basis for viewing the facts as the master viewed them, so you don't want us to get into that.
That is correct, Your Honor.
Is there some book that has... just as a matter of law that has this thing about top bank in it?
Justice Breyer--
Which is the one--
--Mr. McCartney asked that question to Mr. Winkley.
--Aside from this, if we're going to state a proposition of law in some of these opinions, I would like it, you know, to be accurate.
Yes.
Where would I look--
Yes, Your Honor, and I would point the Court to two cases.
--You never heard of the term high bank before, did you?

I have used the term myself, high bank, a number of times throughout this litigation to describe the bank coming from Louisiana or Mississippi where the bank makes a severe slope coming off of the flatland down into the bed of the river.
You had a second case... Smith v. Lattig, and you were going to refer us to a second case.
--Thank you, Justice Kennedy, I was going to do that.
Mr. Bayless, in a case like this, does either side have a burden of proof?
Your Honor, it is our position that Louisiana had the burden of proof.
I think your moment for reviewing your notes has just expired.
Thank you, Your Honor.
General Keyser, you have a little over a minute left.
Thank you.
And what is that definition?
A body of land entirely surrounded by water at ordinary high water.
Yes, all right, but then the issue, it's ordinary high water is the correct term--
--That is the--
--not something like a special median extra-high water, and not top bank, so we should disregard those terms in your view, is that right?
--Except that top bank is the same as ordinary high water.
It doesn't mean, really, the height of the bank.
No.
Thank you.
